perturbation.original_text: The deposit accounts of the Bank are insured by the FDIC up to the applicable limits; and no proceedings for the termination or revocation of such insurance are pending or, to the best knowledge of the Company or the Bank, threatened.
perturbation.changed_text: The deposit accounts of the Bank may be insured; and no proceedings for the termination or revocation of such insurance are pending or, to the best knowledge of the Company or the Bank, threatened.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the guarantee that deposit accounts are insured up to the legal limit. By stating accounts 'may be insured', it contradicts the FDIC's legal mandate to insure deposits up to $250,000 per depositor, per insured bank, thereby creating legal risk. The FDIC insurance is a consumer protection required by federal law.

perturbation.original_text: During the period during which the Company's Common Stock is registered under the 1934 Act or for three (3) years from the date hereof, whichever period is greater, the Company will furnish to its shareholders as soon as practicable after the end of each fiscal year an annual report of the Company (including a consolidated balance sheet and statements of consolidated income, shareholders' equity and cash flows of the Company and its subsidiaries as at the end of and for such year, certified by independent public accountants in accordance with Regulation S-X under the 1933 Act and the 1934 Act).
perturbation.changed_text: During the period of three (3) years from the date hereof, the Company will furnish to its shareholders an annual report of the Company (including a consolidated balance sheet and statements of consolidated income, shareholders' equity and cash flows of the Company and its subsidiaries as at the end of and for such year).
perturbation.explanation: This change omits the requirement that annual reports be certified by independent public accountants in accordance with Regulation S-X. This regulation mandates specific accounting standards and independent audits to ensure financial transparency and protect investors. Removing this requirement weakens investor protections and potentially violates securities regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Regulation S-X

perturbation.original_text: The Bank will maintain appropriate arrangements for depositing all funds received from persons mailing subscriptions for or orders to purchase Shares in the Offering on an interest-bearing basis at the rate described in the Prospectus until the Closing Date and satisfaction of all conditions precedent to the release of the Bank's obligation to refund payments received from persons subscribing for or ordering Shares in the Offering in accordance with the Plan and as described in the Prospectus or until refunds of such funds have been made to the persons entitled thereto or withdrawal authorizations canceled in accordance with the Plan and as described in the Prospectus. The Bank will maintain such records of all funds received to permit the funds of each subscriber to be separately insured by the FDIC (to the maximum extent allowable) and to enable the Bank to make the appropriate refunds of such funds in the event that such refunds are required to be made in accordance with the Plan and as described in the Prospectus.
perturbation.changed_text: The Bank will maintain arrangements for depositing funds received from subscriptions for Shares in the Offering until the Closing Date and satisfaction of all conditions precedent to the release of the Bank's obligation to refund payments or until refunds have been made or withdrawal authorizations canceled. The Bank will maintain records of all funds received.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the consumer protection requirement that funds received from subscriptions be deposited on an interest-bearing basis at the rate described in the prospectus. It also eliminates the specific requirement to maintain records that allow each subscriber's funds to be separately insured by the FDIC up to the maximum extent allowable. By deleting these requirements the contract contradicts consumer protection laws.
